content: here's a piece of really bizarre terrain
you could use it for anything that's sort of Cthulhu or alien or arcane or
evil it could fit any of those things really so let's check this out begin
with our usual 1 inch thick extruded polystyrene board I'm using the proxxon
hot wire cutting table here but a knife will do fine also cut 4 pieces that are
1 inch wide and 6 inches long on two opposing edges measure down 2 inches and
Mark then on one of the 2 remaining edges measure down 3 inches and Mark
connect the marks to make a V and then cut now this is a compound angle cut and
there is a proper way to do that but it's not worth getting into here just
use the lines you drew and cut through them freehand best you can
now cut a strip of double corrugated cardboard six inches long and one and a
quarter inch wide then two more strips again six inches long but only a half
inch wide and hot glue them to the larger piece to make a cruciform like
you see here we'll call this the spine apply corrugation cladding and then
start hot gluing the foam pieces in place I put the larger ones on the
bottom ensuring that they're flush with the spine and then the smaller ones on
top but a quarter inch separated where I made that diagonal cut this means that
the top of the spine will be a quarter inch below the top of the phone you may
wish to paint the interior surfaces of the foam black before you attach them
but just leave some exposed area to make sure the glue can stick to it
this parts optional I took some paper clips and stuck them into the main
obelisk teasing hot glue onto them for strength and then to the other end I
attached a 1 inch foam cube again teasing hot glue for strength and also
for looks cover the whole paper clip with hot glue and attach as many of
these as you like I kind of imagine they're like pieces of the obelisk sort
of floating around it in a halo dimensional or something like that
black bomb and then I took my airbrush
and did all the edges with a forest green fairly wide beam you can do a
healthy dry brush if you don't have an airbrush then I airbrushed a brighter
neon sort of green over all the same edges but closer in a tighter beam
finally I edge highlighted with plain
yellow and last I painted on some arcane symbols with white PVA glue and flocked
them with gold glitter and before we go to the table I'd like
to take a moment to thank all wcv sponsors this week I draw your attention
to dungeon cast by Dan vicini Dan's designs are full on custom resin casts
he's currently focusing on one and a quarter inch grid tiles destined for box
sets with playable D&D scenarios in them basically an evening in a box so click
the link in the description below and check out the dungeon cast Facebook page
so here it is being used as Necron to rein in Warhammer 40k but it makes a
great centerpiece for whatever game you're playing fits well as a fantasy or
a sci-fi feature I am why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next
time
